critique: This executive order amends the Selective Service Regulations of 1948. It primarily deals with exemptions and procedures related to alien registration and classification for selective service. It clarifies which aliens are not required to register, establishes procedures for aliens to be relieved from military service, and allows local boards to issue permits for registrants to leave the United States. The order does not significantly expand executive power, as it operates within the existing framework of the Selective Service Act. It shows a balanced approach to immigration, neither strictly restrictive nor extremely open, by defining specific exemptions. It doesn't directly address economic regulation or social inclusion. The order seems neutral on the ideological tilt, focusing on administrative procedures. It also doesn't heavily prioritize national security over civil liberties, focusing on exemptions and processes. The federalism aspect is neutral, as it works within the existing federal system.
